tossups.question: This element is extracted using cyanide in the MacArthur-Forrest process. Ridaura (“rih-DORA”) and Solganol contain this element bonded to a sugar, and the use of those compounds can lead to chrysiasis (“kris-SIGH-uh-sis”). The interaction between thiols and a layer of this element is a common driving force behind the formation of self-assembled monolayers. A chloride of this element is heated and reduced using sodium citrate to produce a monodisperse solution of (*) nanoparticles of this element. The transition from the 5d orbital to a relativistically-contracted 6s orbital in this element causes it to absorb a disproportionate amount of blue light. Like platinum, this metal can be dissolved in aqua regia. For 10 points, name this metal with symbol Au.

Deborah Swift wrote several novels about female characters “Pleasing” this work’s narrator, who takes an arm bone from a mummy he views and gets a plaster cast made of his face. This work uses a slang of English profanities with French and Italian words to discuss its author's liaisons with the maid Mary Skinner and the actress Elizabeth Knepp. This work describes a man burying wine and Parmesan cheese and chronicled Lord Sandwich's denunciation of the (*) Anglo-Dutch War. This work ended due to the author's strained eyesight. Its narrator describes attending plays and ends passages with the phrase "and so to bed." The author of this work sees "houses marked with a red cross” and the words “Lord have mercy upon us." For 10 points, name this record kept by a 1660s British naval administrator, which has accounts of the Great Plague and the Great Fire of London.
tossups.answer: the diary of Samuel Pepys [or the journal of Samuel Pepys; accept obvious equivalents; Pepys is properly pronounced “Peeps,” but anything that sounds roughly phonetic is fine]

tossups.question: Initiates into this religion undergo a ceremony in which an elder will circle an egg around the initiate’s head seven times to ward off evil. Priests of this religion hold ceremonies in which flowers are placed on metal trays; those ceremonies, called Afringans, typically take place on top of a sofreh, or a white cloth while the priest wears a jama. Priests in this religion hold jashan celebrations for families and 32 priests are required to find 16 different sources of a substance, commonly found in Udvada, in order to create the (*) Behram, or “of Victory” variety. The Achu Michu ceremony accompanies the Navjote (“nav-JOTE”) ceremony for initiates into this religion who are expected to wear the sedreh undershirt and kushti belt. Nusessalars filter out the bones of this religion’s deceased practitioners after they are collected from Towers of Silence. People offer sandalwood into fires at temples dedicated to, for 10 points, what Persian religion which worships Ahura Mazda?

A sonnet from this century that lists its five primary artistic qualities is cited in a book by John Shearman, which also describes the disapproval of the next century’s critic Giovanni Bellori. A depiction of Moses Defending the Daughters of Jethro was painted during this century by an artist who unusually included three different ladders in a crowded Deposition. An Italian word for “style” lends its name to an artistic style throughout this century that included the School of (*) Fontainebleau and the work of Rosso Fiorentino. The figura serpentinata and bright colors of a style in this century are emphasized in a Deposition painted by Jacopo Pontormo. A Madonna with the Long Neck was painted during this century by Parmigianino. For 10 points, elongated proportions were emphasized as part of the Mannerist style during what century?

They’re not factory workers, but severe mercury poisoning led to a 1970 outbreak of Minamata disease among these people near the town of Dryden, leading to the introduction of their Health Transfer Policy. After the Calder Supreme Court Case, the government backed away from a 1969 White Paper advocating the abrogation of all legal documents regarding these people. Elijah Harper held an (*) eagle feather while filibustering the Meech Lake Accords for its lack of input from these people. The Red River Expedition put down a rebellion of a mixed-race group of these people led by Louis Riel known as the Métis (“meh-TEE”). In 2008, these people received an apology for being forcibly assimilated through residential schools from Prime Minister Stephen Harper. For 10 points, name these original inhabitants of Canada.
tossups.answer: First Nations [or First Peoples; or clear equivalents to Native Americans in Canada or indigenous peoples of Canada until read; prompt on natives or indigenous peoples by asking “from which country?”; anti-prompt on specific groups like the Métis or Ojibwe (“oh-JEEB-way”) or Cree with “can you be less specific?”; do not accept or prompt on “Native Americans” or equivalents referring to indigenous groups from any other country]

tossups.question: Programs written in this paradigm can eliminate intermediate lists and tree structures through a technique that relies on shortcut fusion; that technique is deforestation. The dispatch macro is symbolized by a pound sign in a language in this paradigm; a subset of that language in this paradigm is the extensible data notation format. A book by Miran Lipova urges “Learn you” one language in this paradigm “for Great Good!” Referential transparency is guaranteed in the (*) pure form of this paradigm, which prevents side effects. This paradigm supports currying, a technique which is used to implement higher-order constructs like “map” and “fold.” This programming paradigm is modeled on the lambda calculus, and examples include OCaml, Clojure, and Haskell. For 10 points, name this programming paradigm often contrasted with imperative programming.

In a novel named for this concept, the narrator is scared by a woman with one long tooth and decides to freak out another woman by repeating “You are losing your book, madam!” at her. The narrator of one novel with this name constantly writes “1848” and tries to sell an essay about Correggio before leaving for England. That narrator of a novel with this name repeatedly pawns his clothing and has a relationship with Ylajali (“ee-la-YAH-lee”). In a story partially named for this concept, a man who experiences it is watched by three butchers and successively told “we do (*) admire it” and “we don’t admire it.” In a story named for this concept, a man is guarded in a straw-filled cage for forty-day stretches and eventually replaced by a panther. A circus performer claims to be an “artist” of this thing in a namesake Kafka story. For 10 points, name this concept that titles a novel by Knut (“ca-NOOT”) Hamsun.
tossups.answer: hunger [or “The Hunger Artist” or “Ein Hungerkünstler” or Sult]

tossups.question: In an orchestral piece by this composer, a section marked allegro volando functions as a loose sonata exposition, whose first theme is identified with the “flight of the spirit” by critics. In his seventh piano sonata, this composer included directions to play “comme des éclairs” (“KOHM dez eh-clair”) or “like flashes of lightning.” This composer’s fourth piano sonata has only two movements, both in F-sharp major, with the second movement marked prestissimo volando. This composer’s interest in (*) theosophy inspired him to associate the note C with red and D with bright yellow. The notes C, F-sharp, B-flat, E, A, and D make up the ‘mystic chord’ which he used in the last five of his ten piano sonatas. This composer’s Poem of Ecstasy is sometimes labeled as his fourth symphony. For 10 points, name this eccentric Russian composer of the “White Mass” and “Black Mass” piano sonatas.

A Renaissance king of this country founded the short-lived Universitas Istropolitana and patronized one of Europe’s largest book collections. In some churches, the “Noon Bell” still rings to commemorate a victory in the former capital of another country by this kingdom because Pope Callixtus III never withdrew an order to pray for its defenders. An unusually well-armed corps of mercenaries named the (*) Black Army served this kingdom’s monarch until its dissolution by Vladislaus II. After his king died at the Battle of Varna John Hunyadi successfully defended Belgrade and became regent of this country. The last non-Habsburg king of this country died drowning in a stream during the Battle of Mohács (“MO-hawtch”). Monarchs of this realm like Matthias Corvinus were coronated in Székesfehérvár (“SAY-kesh-feh-her-var”) with the Crown of St. Stephen. For 10 points, name this country which formed a dual monarch with Austria until 1918.

This legal document sought to establish "economic democracy" by borrowing an Irish document's use of non-enforceable "directive principles." This document's foundational features cannot be altered according to the basic structure doctrine. Along with outlining fundamental rights, this document lists "scientific temper" as one of 11 fundamental duties. It is the longest document of its type in the world due to numerous amendments, including a recent invalidation of Article 370 that created two (*) union territories. This document's Article 338A provides for a National Commission for Scheduled Tribes. The words "secular" and "socialist" were added to its preamble during the 1970's, when invocation of its Article 352 allowed for "rule by decree" during the Emergency. So-called "backward classes " are given affirmative action by, for 10 points, what 1950 document drafted by B.R. Ambedkar?
tossups.answer: The Constitution of India [or Bhāratīya Saṃvidhāna; accept variations like Indian Constitution]

tossups.question: The speaker of this poem mentions a time “before the gray Depression” when the central figure of this poem would sit “crossleg on the grass—her long hair wound with flowers—smiling” and read stories from “a Communist fairy book.” The speaker of this poem also recalls “long nites as a child in Paterson apartment, watching over your nervousness,” and talks of a paranoid person who thought she was poisoned during a (*) hospital stay. This poem contains a section titled “Hymmnn” spelled with two m’s and n’s which contains the phrases “your withered thighs” and “the gaunt of your cheek.” This poem repeats the phrase “Blessed be” and opens with the line “Strange now to think of you, gone without corsets & eyes.” For 10 points, name this elegy for the author’s mother Naomi written by Allen Ginsberg, titled after the Jewish prayer of mourning.

In one disease, these cells aggregate into Pautrier (“PAW-tree-ay”) microabscesses. Their nuclei can take on a brain-like, or cerebriform, appearance in Sezary syndrome. CCR7 expression is used to distinguish the “central” and “effector” type of one subset of these cells. Protein kinase inhibitors can enhance staining of these cells with fluorophore-labelled tetramers before flow cytometry. Alefacept (“uh-LEFF-uh-sept”) and cyclosporine A bind to proteins on or in these cells. Some of these cells that react too strongly with mTECs undergo (*) apoptosis in a process called negative selection. These cells are initially CD3, CD4, and CD8 positive but lose either CD4 or CD8 when they develop in the thymus. For 10 points, name these immune cells which occur in cytotoxic and helper varieties.

This concept is distinguished from the Mit-sein because it lacks ontological duality. In a “Key to Special Terminology,” this concept is said to “rest on a vacillation between transcendence and facticity.” A “serious man” who “does not even imagine… getting out of the world” and “has given to himself the type of existence of the rock,” is held up as an example of this idea. This concept and (*) “sincerity” are held to be similar in their essential structure, because sincerity is “a constant effort to dissociate oneself from oneself.” This concept is illustrated with the example of a waiter whose “movement… is too precise,” and who “plays with” his condition in order to realize it. For 10 points, identify this concept which indicates a kind of willful self-deception about one’s freedom to act, developed in Being and Nothingness by Jean-Paul Sartre.
tossups.answer: bad faith [or mauvaise foi; accept self-deception until it is read]]

tossups.question: While serving as a counterinsurgency officer, this man radicalized himself with insurgent literature he found, including a biography of Ezequiel Zamora. The Tascón List made public the names of citizens who had signed a petition to recall this leader. Coordinadora Democrática organized a crippling general strike of employees of the PDVSA opposed to this President to force a new election. While this leader repeatedly interrupted the (*) Prime Minister of Spain at a summit, King Juan Carlos famously asked him “Why don’t you shut up?” This soldier planned to assassinate Carlos Andrés Pérez as part of a failed coup carried out by his MBR-200 group. This president who joked about the sulfur George Bush left behind on the UN podium organized supporters into workers’ councils called Bolivarian Circles. For 10 points, name this deceased predecessor of Nicolás Maduro as leader of Venezuela.

Description acceptable. In reference to the movie School Daze, this event had several characters called “Bug-a-boos” line up and try to make a woman with black chevrons on her sleeves laugh. This event referenced the song “Lilac Wine” by Nina Simone as well as Malcolm X’s speech “Who Taught You to Hate Yourself?” and the letters “Beta Delta Kappa” appeared as a central motif. This event began with a procession led by a woman dressed as (*) Nefertiti. Along with a full marching band, the main performer at this event was accompanied by the background dancers “Les Twins.” Preparation for this event was documented in Homecoming, and this event was postponed for a year when its performer unexpectedly became pregnant with twins. For 10 points, name this 2018 performance, which marked the first time a black woman headlined a certain California music festival.
tossups.answer: Beychella [accept Beyoncé’s 2018 Coachella performance; accept equivalents; prompt on Coachella alone]

tossups.question: In this director’s first English-language feature, the opening credits roll over the surface of the protagonist’s eyeball in an extreme close-up of the eye, and that protagonist later hallucinates that she sees groping hands burst through the walls of a shadowy hallway. That film by this director chronicles Carole Ledoux’s (“le-DOO”) descent into madness due to her anxieties over sexuality. This director is fictionalized as the neighbor of Rick Dalton in (*) Tarantino’s Once Upon a Time in Hollywood. In another film by this director of Repulsion, the protagonist is sheltered by a German officer after playing Chopin’s Ballade in G minor. He was not present to collect the Best Director Oscar for that biopic about Władisław (“vwa-di-swaf”) Spillman, having fled the United States in 1978 to escape charges of statutory rape. For 10 points, name this Polish-French director of The Pianist and Chinatown.

In his speech “Democracy and Education,” this man criticized the focus on liberal arts education, lamenting that he could sooner find teachers of Latin than tailoring. This man collaborated with Sears president Julius Rosenwald to build almost five thousand schools, and this close friend of Standard Oil executive Harry Rogers worked with Andrew Carnegie to found the National Negro Business League in 1900. Senator Benjamin Tillman proposed killing a thousand people to remedy the effects of this man’s (*) White House dinner with Theodore Roosevelt. This man told whites that they could exist “as separate as the fingers” from blacks in a speech where he declared “cast down your bucket where you are” at the Atlanta Exposition. For 10 points, name this African-American reformer and author of Up from Slavery who founded the Tuskegee Institute.

In one poem by this author, the narrator is “sailing for fun / on a lake of great allure” before smelling and then seeing “A foul fish, with death replete, / At the bottom of the well.” Another poem by this author includes a description of “wings that were surging/ From beautiful women’s shoulders.” This man wrote about an object that he keeps “In July as in January” and for both a “true friend” and a “cruel person.” This author of “I Cultivate a White Rose” wrote a poem whose narrator knows “how to name and class/ All the strange flowers that grow” and says “I come from everywhere / And everywhere I go.” That poem by this author of (*) “Our America” describes a “traveller to all parts” who considers himself a “sincere man.” For 10 points, name this poet whose collection Versos Sencillos includes “Guantanamera,” a fighter for Cuban independence.

A term meaning a disc of these creatures refers both to Sol and the sun-chariot he rides across the sky prior to Ragnarok. Jacob Grimm’s namesake trinity refers to two varieties of these creatures, the former of which is said to be “fairer than the sun to look at.” In the Völundarkviða (“VOL-on-dark-VITH-uh”), Volundr, or Wayland, is described as the prince of the creatures. Vidblainn separates from a region named for these beings, a region which the Grimnismal claims was given to Freyr as a “tooth-gift.” Goethe’s poem (*) Erlkönig is commonly thought to refer to a king of these creatures. These creatures typically come in dark and light varieties, the latter of which also refers to their realm. Commonly contrasted with dwarves are, for 10 points, what Germanic creatures depicted with pointy ears?
tossups.answer: elf [or elves; accept dark or light elves or svartálfar or Dökkálfar or Ljósálfar]

tossups.question: In one graph describing this force, the Hersey number is plotted on the x-axis. This force is expressed as a piecewise continuous function in the Karnopp model, and the nonlinear behavior of this force can be seen on the Stribeck curve. The work done by this force is divided by hardness to calculate a volume quantity in the Archard equation, which assumes this force is due to (*) asperities. The study of bodies subject to this force is tribology. A coefficient used to calculate this force equals the tangent of the angle at which an object begins to slide down the slope. For 10 points, name this nonconservative force with kinetic and static varieties that resists motion.

bonuses.leadin: In 2019, this country’s leader appeared in a state television broadcast driving donuts around a flaming crater known as the “Door to Hell” to prove he was not dead. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Central Asian country where geologists set fire to the Darvaza crater in 1971 to prevent the spread of methane gas. This country’s Galkynysh Gas Field is the second-largest in the world after Iran’s South Pars field.
Turkmenistan has sought to boost tourism to the Darvaza crater and to the Awaza resort on this largest inland body of water, which is fed by the Volga River.
The Darvaza crater and Turkmenistan’s gas reserves are located in this desert named for its dark subsurface soil, where a namesake canal carries water to irrigate cotton-growing oases like Mary.

bonuses.leadin: Paul Signac (“sin-YAHK”) titled a book after the Dutch landscape painter Johan Jongkind, who influenced a painter in this town named Louis Eugène Boudin. For 10 points each:
answers: Impressionism [or Impression, Sunrise; or Impression, soleil levant]
parts: Name this hometown where an artist started out by selling caricatures for twenty francs. At an exhibition at the former studio of the photographer Nadar, a painting of this town was unfavorably compared to unfinished wallpaper.
That painting of Le Havre’s harbor by Claude Monet lends its name to this artistic movement that aimed to depict fleeting changes in light and color.
Boudin taught Monet to paint in this manner, which was made easier by the box easel and pochade box. This technique of painting outdoors has a two or three-word French name.

bonuses.leadin: This value describes a state in which the forward and reverse reaction rates are equal. For 10 points each:
answers: delta-G [or the change in the Gibbs free energy; do not accept or prompt on “Gibbs free energy” or “G”]
parts: Name this constant symbolized with an uppercase K, which is calculated by dividing products by reactants. Comparing the reaction quotient to this value gives the direction of a reaction.
Negative RT times the natural logarithm of the equilibrium constant is equal to this value.

Negative one over the equilibrium constant for ligand dissociation equals the slope on one of these plots. The x-axis on these plots show the concentration of bound radioligand, and on the y is bound over free radioligand.

bonuses.leadin: Susan Haack’s book Evidence and Inquiry advocates for an epistemology that combines this position with foundationalism. For 10 points each:
answers: coherentism [accept coherence theory or any word form]
parts: Identify this epistemic view, according to which the reason for believing some proposition is related to the reasons you might have for believing other related propositions.
This philosopher’s 1912 work The Problems of Philosophy argued against coherence theory by pointing out that coherentists presuppose the laws of logic, which themselves do not cohere with anything.

Haack has argued repeatedly against Rorty’s interpretation of this philosopher. This author of “How to Make Our Ideas Clear” and “The Fixation of Belief” is generally held to be the founder of Pragmatism.

bonuses.leadin: The Man in the Moon declares “the old earth is frolicsome tonight!” after seeing a crowd of people laughing at this man. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this British official who is tarred and feathered in Boston by a mob led by a man with his face painted red and black. This man promises the youth Robin a job, but Robin realizes he can succeed without this relative.

In a story by the author of “My Kinsman, Major Molineux,” this woman works in the lethal garden of her scientist father Giacomo, which turns her poisonous. This woman dies when her lover Giovanni tries to give her an antidote.

This author of “My Kinsman, Major Molineux” and “Rappacini’s Daughter” also created a man who turns to stone in “The Man of Adamant” and a man who dies after giving a sermon on a scaffold, Arthur Dimmesdale.

bonuses.leadin: Royal inscriptions in this ancient city including the epitaph on the sarcophagus of King Ahiram attest the Phoenician script. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city located in modern-day Lebanon that dominated Phoenician trade along with Tyre and Sidon. A Roman-era historian from this city named Philo translated the Phoenician history of Sanchuniathon.
The name of Byblos bears great resemblance to the Greek word for “book” possibly because it was a center for the export of this Egyptian reed used for writing materials.

The undeciphered pre-Phoenician Byblos syllabary bears a close relationship to the hieratic script of this Egyptian period. Pharaohs during this period built the Pyramids at Giza and employed Imhotep.

bonuses.leadin: This figure was shot in the mouth by a blow dart, prompting two gods to disguise themselves and replace his teeth with corn. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this father of Cabarakan and Zipacna whose K’iche name was Vucub-Caquix (“WOO-cub KA-kix”). He tore off the arm of Hunaphu (“HU-nah-pu”).
Seven-Macaw was defeated by the Hero Twins of this myth system, whose main epic, the Popol Vuh, describes adventures in the underworld Xibalba (“shee-BALL-buh”).

Seven-Macaw’s son Zipacna mocks a group of this many boys for their inability to lift a column, prompting them to attempt to kill him with it. Huitzilopochtli (“WEET-see-loh-POACH-tlee”) prepares to kill this many brothers named the Centzonuitznaua (“SENT-so-nweetz-NOW-uh”) and his sister Coyolxauhqui (“coh-YOHL-shau-kee”) at his birth.

bonuses.leadin: This man attempted to defend himself from criticism of his most famous work by including the story of a man who lived on a mountain with his son, who had never been off the mountain and was fascinated by women when he finally left. For 10 points each:
answers: he can ignore the day’s topic while telling his story [accept equivalents]
parts: Name this author who created the storytelling Panfilo, Pampinea, and Filostrato in the Decameron.
This “patient” character in the Decameron is tested by her husband Gualtieri, who pretends to kill their children and marry his twelve-year-old daughter.
Description acceptable. The last of the ten storytellers from the Decameron, Dioneo, had this special right when telling stories because of his wit.

bonuses.leadin: One consequence of this result is that it is impossible to make a particle’s total spin point entirely along one axis. For 10 points each:
answers: Heisenberg uncertainty principle [prompt on Heisenberg principle]
canonical commutation relation [or fundamental commutation prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this statement which makes it impossible to measure two conjugate operators, such as position and momentum, to arbitrary precision.

The position and momentum operators obey this general relation, which states that x times p minus p times x equals i times h-bar. This type of relation holds for any conjugate observables subject to the uncertainty principle.

A specific case of this theorem relates the expectation value of momentum to mass times the time derivative of position. More generally, this theorem states that expectation values of position and momentum operators obey classical laws.

bonuses.leadin: This country’s civil war factions agreed to a truce after its soccer team qualified for the 2006 World Cup. For 10 points each:
answers: Félix Houphouët-Boigny (“oo-FWAY bwan-YEE”) [do not accept or prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this country which holds the largest church in the world, the Basilica of Our Lady of Peace, in its capital of Yamoussoukro.

This longtime president lavished funds on the building of the Basilica in his hometown. This dictator opposed Ahmed Sekou Toure and Kwame Nkrumah and invested in cocoa and coffee to spearhead the “Ivorian Miracle.”
Houphouët-Boigny was the chief African ally of this European country, who pursued a policy of close alliance with former colonies like Cote d’Ivoire.

bonuses.leadin: The Netherlands’ contributions to music go beyond electronic dance DJs. For 10 points each:
parts: In Amsterdam, Dietrich Nikolaus Winkel invented this device for keeping musical time, though he called it a “musical chronometer.” Winkel neglected to patent this device, so the German inventor Johann Maelzel got credit.

This Dutch early baroque composer served as organist at Amsterdam’s Oude Kerk from 1580 until his death, during which time he composed pioneering echo fantasias and Variations on “Mein junges Leben hat ein End.”

While in Amsterdam, François and Pieter Hemony perfected this instrument, which uses a keyboard to ring bells suspended in a tower. The Netherlands gifted one of these instruments to the US which is now in Arlington Cemetery.

bonuses.leadin: A student at this institution cut off his arm to prove his dedication to his teacher after having stood in the freezing cold all night. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this institution where a leader faced a wall for nine years after being initially refused entry. That leader of this institution left some books behind in a chest which his students later found.
That aforementioned teacher was this patriarch of Chan, or Zen Buddhism, known for spreading it to China.

Bodhidharma was erroneously held to have brought this sport into common practice at the monastery. A group of men forming the “Society of Righteous and Harmonious Fists” led a rebellion named for this sport during the Qing dynasty.

bonuses.leadin: This man pioneered instrument flying, helping to develop the attitude and heading indicators. For 10 points each:
answers: Soviet Union [or USSR; prompt on Russia]
parts: Name this lieutenant colonel who in 1942 led sixteen B25 bombers off the USS Hornet to strike the Japanese home islands before bailing out over China.

After bailing out, Doolittle encountered this American officer who helped smuggle Doolittle beyond Japanese lines. Chinese communists killed this missionary eleven days after the end of the war, making him “the first casualty of the Cold War.”
While fifteen of Doolittle’s bombers crash-landed in China, one crew landed in Vladivostok and spent a year interned in this country because of its neutrality pact with Japan.

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. Toloki finds a career doing this thing professionally in Zakes Mda’s (“muh-DAH’s”) Ways of Dying. For 10 points each:
answers: mourning the dead [accept mourning a family member or attending funerals; be lenient]
parts: Name this process, which requires the father of Olunde to commit ritual suicide in another work.
Tambu fails to mourn the death of her older brother Nhamo because it means there will be money for her to go to missionary school in this novel by Tsitsi Dangarembga (“tuh-SIT-see dan-gar-EMB-gah”).
Elesin’s son Olunde commits ritual suicide to mourn the death of their king in Death and the King’s Horseman, a play by this author.

bonuses.leadin: Surface structures on this object include the Cthulhu Macula (“kuh-THOO-loo MAC-yu-lah”) and the “Brass Knuckles.” For 10 points each:
answers: hydrogen [or H; or H2, or hydrogen gas]
parts: Name this dwarf planet that is orbited by Charon, Nyx, and Hydra. It was formerly the ninth planet from the sun.
This NASA probe flew by Pluto in July 2015. It subsequently studied several Kuiper belt objects, including Ultima Thule.
The New Horizons spacecraft confirmed a “wall” of this substance just beyond the heliopause. At redshift z equals 1089, this substance reionized.

bonuses.leadin: Hubert Pierlot declared a king of this name unfit to govern and appointed his brother Prince Charles as regent after he refused to join Pierlot’s government in exile. For 10 points each:
answers: Leopold [or Leopold III; or Leopold II]
School Wars [or Second School War; or First School War]
parts: Give this name of a king who abdicated in 1950 because of a general strike over his 1940 surrender to the Nazis. Adam Hochschild detailed the atrocities of that man’s uncle of the same name in a book on his “ghost.”
This country’s “Royal Question” concerned the political crisis over Leopold III’s fitness for the throne. This country’s region of Flanders supported the king while Wallonia opposed him.

Soon after the Royal Question, this social conflict began after Socialist Leo Collard reversed the subsidies and wage increases of his Christian Social predecessor. The first of these conflicts began after the “Papist Biter” Walthère Frère-Orban passed a sweeping secularization law in 1879.

bonuses.leadin: An experiment by Donald Dutton and Arthur Aron tested the misattribution of this state by having subjects speak to an attractive woman before stepping on a bridge. For 10 points each:
answers: arousal [or being aroused; prompt on "alertness" or equivalents like "being amped up"]
parts: Name this heightened sensory state caused by activation of the ascending reticular activating system.

An inverted U-shaped law describing the relationship between performance and arousal was developed by this man and John Dillingham Dodson. This man also propagated eugenics by issuing Alpha and Beta intelligence tests to World War I draftees.

Unlike the James-Lange and Cannon-Bard theories of emotion, Jerome Singer and Stanley Schachter proposed that emotions arise from two factors: physiological arousal and this attempt by the mind to causally connect an outside event with the emotion.

bonuses.leadin: This author worked in the RAF, which he described in his first short story “A Piece of Cake,” before his time as a British spy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author who worked under William Stephenson as a spy in Washington, D. C. His numerous sexual liaisons there possibly inspired his work My Uncle Oswald.

This author used the codenames “Agent 160” and “Astrea” to go on a spying mission to Belgium under King Charles II, as well as a possible trip to Suriname, where a slave uprising may have inspired her novel Oroonoko.
This author of The Power and The Glory drew on his experience as a spy for MI6 to write Our Man in Havana.

bonuses.leadin: One problem with the hypothesis that this molecule began life is that cytosine lacks stability on geologic timescales even at low temperatures. For 10 points each:
answers: PAHs [or polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, or polyaromatic hydrocarbons, prompt on answers mentioning aromatics]
parts: Name this nucleic acid which contains ribose. Its namesake “world” is a hypothetical stage in the evolution of life that preceded cells.

A hypothesis by Simon Platts that supports the RNA world suggests that these organic compounds, which are cosmically abundant, could have catalyzed early polymerization of RNA by stacking alongside RNA.
The term “RNA world” was coined by this scientist, who with Allan Maxam developed a method of DNA sequencing requiring tagging the 5’ (“five-prime”) end with radioactive phosphate.

bonuses.leadin: In a crayon and watercolor sketch, Claes Oldenburg (“KLAHSS OLD-en-burkh”) proposed replacing the main landmark of this site with a “Colossal Monument” of a “Gearshift in Motion.” For 10 points each:
answers: a ship [or a boat; or Nelson's Ship in a Bottle]
Assyrian empire [or Assyria; or Neo-Assyrian empire]
parts: Katharina Frisch’s Hahn/Cock and Hans Haacke’s Gift Horse were large sculptures created for the Fourth Plinth in what public location?

Yinka Shonibare, who was shortlisted for the Turner Prize, created one of these objects for his Fourth Plinth piece. Turner himself painted one of these objects also present at the Battle of Trafalgar in his Fighting Temeraire.

As of 2019, the Fourth Plinth is occupied by a Michael Rakowitz sculpture made of date cans, which depicts a lamassu from this empire. ISIS destroyed the artifact the piece is based on when they attacked Mosul’s museum in 2015.
